For three-way catalysts (TWC) applied in lean burn gasoline engines for passive selective catalytic reduction (pSCR) operation, besides the conversion efficiency of HC/CO/NO, the production of NH3 is also an important concern. In this work, La2O3 was introduced into the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst system, the influence on its TWC performance for pSCR operation was investigated, and the physicochemical properties were characterized by a range of techniques. The results reveal that the introduced La2O3 mainly interacts with Al2O3 by preferentially anchoring to the tetra-coordinated Al sites on the surface. When the catalyst is modified by appropriate amount of La2O3 (4 wt%), higher dispersion of Pd species, larger amount of Pd2+ and active oxygen species are achieved, which well contributes to improved low-temperature reduction ability and NH3 desorption property of the catalyst. As a consequence, excellent catalytic conversions of HC/CO/NO are obtained, and meanwhile, higher concentration of NH3 is generated, making the modified catalyst more promising for pSCR operation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords TWC for pSCR operation NH3 La2O3 Pd/Al2O3 Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Nowadays, in spite of the increasing prevalence of alternative fuels and renewable energy, petroleum-based fuels are still accounted for the vast majority of transportation energy, wherein a large portion of petroleum energy is consumed by gasoline-engined vehicles. Owing to the requirements of energy conservation, emission reduction and fuel consumption regulations, gasoline engines with higher thermal efficiency have become a pursuing goal. Under this circumstance, lean burn gasoline engines are a promising technology, which can increase the adiabatic index of the fuel mixture, reduce the combustion temperature, and consequently remarkably improved thermal efficiency can be achieved [1]. By applying improved engine technology, lean burn engines provide higher air-to-fuel ratio relative to conventional stoichiometric engines, in this case, the fuel economy can be increased by about 10% [2,3], and meanwhile, the emissions of greenhouse gas can be effectively lowered down [4]. As is well known, typical three-way catalysts (TWCs) possess considerably high efficiency for simultaneous conversions of CO, HC and NOx only in a narrow region around the stoichiometric condition [5-8]. However, owing to the oxygen-rich atmosphere in lean burn engines, the reduction of NOx to N2 over TWCs appears to be much more difficult [3,9]. Therefore, in order to achieve widespread commercial application of lean burn engines, it is of critical importance to diminish the elevated NOx emissions. Passive selective catalytic reduction (pSCR) is a potential approach for the treatment of NOx generated from lean burn gasoline engines [10-14]. A designed pSCR system is typically composed of a close-coupled TWC and a downstream SCR. For conventional researches concerning TWCs, NH3 has long been recognized as a secondary pollutant from gasoline engine emissions [15-19]. However, recently it has been proposed that in pSCR system, the on-board production of NH3 can act as the reductant for the subsequent SCR of NOx [1]. That is, when the engine is operated under stoichiometric or slightly rich condition, NOx would be partially reduced to NH3 over TWC, and the generated NH3 could be stored on the downstream SCR catalyst. During lean burn condition, NOx flows through SCR and reacts with the stored NH3 [4,9]. In this approach, the equipment of additional components such as urea storage tanks and urea injection system is avoided, which are typically included in diesel SCR techniques [4]. While plenty of researches have been conducted to optimize the TWC activity for simultaneous elimination of HC, CO and NOx in the past decades, recently design of highly effective TWC formulations for pSCR system is attracted increasing attention [11]. Herein, besides the conversion efficiency of HC, CO and NOx, the production of NH3 is also a key consideration when evaluating the TWC activity. As reported in the literatures, TWCs composed of Pt or Pd supported on Al2O3 are quite effective for production of NH3, wherein the supported Pd catalysts appear to be more promising on account of its higher efficiency for water gas shift reaction, which can produce more H2 to promote the reduction of NOx to NH3 [18,20]. In addition, La2O3 is a commonly used auxiliary in commercial TWCs in respect that it can act as a stabilizing agent for Al2O3 and a promoter for active component Pd as well, moreover, La2O3 is reported to be able to promote the catalytic conversion of NO during three-way catalytic reaction process [21-25]. In this study, Pd/La2O3/Al2O3 catalysts with different contents of La2O3 were synthesized, the influence of La2O3 on TWC performance of Pd/Al2O3 in pSCR system was investigated, besides the conversion efficiency of HC/CO/NO, particular attention was also paid to the production of NH3. Moreover, the Pd/La2O3/Al2O3 catalysts were characterized through a range of techniques to disclose the relationship between the physicochemical properties and their catalytic performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of the Pd/La2O3/Al2O3 catalysts Bare Pd/Al2O3 catalyst without the addition of La2O3 was synthesized as follows: Firstly, 4.0 g of Al2O3 powders (which had been previously treated at 700 °C) were submitted to thermal treating at 1000 °C for 4 h in a muffle furnace. Then, required amount of Pd(NO3)2 solution (the content of Pd was 0.106 g) was diluted with distilled water and impregnated onto the above Al2O3 powders. Afterwards the impregnated mixture was calcined at 400 °C for 2 h, which was then ball milled with pseudo-boehmite, acetic acid and distilled water to obtain a slurry. After that the slurry was washcoated onto a cordierite honeycomb matrix, after further calcining at 550 °C for 2 h, the obtained monolithic Pd/Al2O3 catalyst was hereafter referred to as La0. In addition, the remaining slurry was dried and calcined at 550 °C for 2 h to obtain the corresponding powder catalyst, which was used to conduct the subsequent characterization experiments. Pd/La2O3/Al2O3 catalyst with La2O3 content of 2 wt% was prepared as follows: Firstly, 0.2128 g of La(NO3)3·6H2O (the content of La2O3 was 37.6 wt%) was dissolved by distilled water and then impregnated onto 4.0 g of Al2O3 powders (which had been previously treated at 700 °C), after thermally treated at 1000 °C for 4 h, the obtained La2O3/Al2O3 powders were impregnated by diluted Pd(NO3)2 solution. Then the impregnated mixture was calcined at 400 °C for 2 h to obtain the catalyst powders. After that, the slurrying, washcoating and calcining processes were the same with those for La0, and the obtained sample was henceforward labeled as La2. Furthermore, another two Pd/La2O3/Al2O3 catalysts with La2O3 contents of 4 wt% and 8 wt% were synthesized applying the same procedure with that for La2, except that the amount of La(NO3)3·6H2O used in the first step was changed to 0.4256 g and 0.8511 g, and the corresponding catalysts were named as La4 and La8, respectively. 2.2 Evaluation of the three-way catalytic performance The catalytic performance of the monolithic catalysts was evaluated in a gas mixture that simulated actual gasoline engine emissions, the composition was as follows: C3H8: 120 ppm; C3H6: 240 ppm; CO: 5100 ppm; NO: 1000 ppm; H2: 1700 ppm; O2: 4580 ppm; H2O: 100,000 ppm; CO2: 100,000 ppm; N2 was used as the balance and the space velocity was controlled at 40,000 h −1. The detailed testing procedure was as follows: Firstly, the monolithic catalyst was placed in the reactor, and the above-mentioned gas mixture was passed through, then the reactor was heated to 550 °C and held for 1 h to activate the catalyst. After that the catalyst was cooled down to ca. 150 °C, and then the temperature was programmed rising, during this process, the compositions of the inlet and outlet gas mixtures were analyzed by an FTIR. Accordingly, the conversions of CO, HC and NO were calculated, and the concentration of NH3 was obtained as well. Moreover, to verify the stability of the catalysts, they were exposed in the reactive gas mixture at 550 °C for 100 h, after that their catalytic performance was evaluated once again. 2.3 Characterization of the catalysts The textural parameters of the catalysts were measured using a surface area & pore size analyzer (V-SordX800, Gold APP Instruments Corporation, Beijing). Before the measurement, the samples were pretreated at 300 °C for 2–5 h under vacuum, then N2 was used as the adsorbate, and the adsorption-desorption experiment was conducted at liquid nitrogen temperature (−196 °C). The phase identification of the catalysts were conducted by an X-ray diffractometer (DX-2500, Rigaku), Cu Kα (λ = 0.15406 nm) was employed as the radiation source. The powder samples were uniformly spread onto a quartz glass plate, which was then placed at the sample stage and continuously scanned in the 2θ range of 10°−90° with a step size of 0.02°. The coordination state of Al in the catalysts was analyzed by a solid state nuclear magnetic resonance (SSNMR, Bruker 300 M). 27Al SSNMR spectra were obtained at room temperature in a 9.4 T magnetic field. The dispersion of Pd species for the catalysts was determined by CO chemisorption experiment. Prior to the chemisorption measurement, the catalyst was pretreated in H2 atmosphere (20 mL/min) at 400 °C for 1 h, and then it was purged in N2 (30 mL/min) for 30 min. After cooling down to near room temperature, CO was pulsed every 2 min until no adsorption could be detected. The surface elemental information of the catalysts was analyzed by a Thermo Scientific™ K-Alpha™+ spectrometer equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV), the measurement was operated at 100 W. All peaks would be calibrated with C1s peak at a binding energy of 284.8 eV for adventitious carbon. The surface morphology of the catalysts was observed on a scanning electron microscope (ZEISS) operated at 20 kV. Then the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were collected applying a ZEISS Libra 200 FE electron microscope operated at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiment was carried out on an automatic temperature programmed chemisorbed instrument (Vodo Instrument Co., Ltd., Quzhou). Prior to the reduction experiment, the powder samples were firstly pressed into granules with appropriate size, then 100 mg of granules were placed into a quartz tube. After that N2 (20 mL/min) was passed through, and the samples were pretreated in N2 at 450 °C for 45 min. After cooled down to room temperature, the atmosphere was switched to 5 vol% H2/N2 (20 mL/min). And then temperature programmed reduction was proceeded at a constant heating rate of 10 °C/min, and the variation of H2 signal was monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiment was also performed on the above mentioned automatic temperature programmed chemisorbed instrument. The detailed process was as follows: Firstly, 100 mg of sample granules were placed into a quartz tube, which were pretreated in an Ar atmosphere (20 mL/min) at 400 °C for 45 min. After cooled down to room temperature, a gas mixture of 0.5 vol% NH3/Ar (30 mL/min) was passed through and held for 30 min. Then temperature programmed desorption was proceeded at a constant heating rate of 10 °C/min, and the variation of NH3 signal was monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The three-way catalytic performance The three-way catalytic performance, in terms of conversions of C3H8, C3H6, CO, NO as well as the concentration of NH3 as function of temperature, is illustrated in Fig. 1 . As displayed therein, compared with La0, the La2O3-modified catalysts approximately show higher conversions of C3H8, C3H6, CO and NO throughout the experimental temperature range, especially for La4 with La2O3 content of 4 wt%, demonstrating that the introduction of appropriate amount of La2O3 into the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst system is beneficial to the catalytic conversions of HC/CO/NO. On the other hand, for the purpose of verification its application potential in pSCR system, particular attention should be paid to the production of NH3 during the catalytic reaction process. Fortunately, it can be found from Fig. 1(e) that the concentration of NH3 over La4 and La8 is obviously higher than that over La0 throughout the whole testing process, wherein La4 behaves somewhat better compared with La8. Therefore, it can be concluded that the introduction of appropriate amount of La2O3 into Pd/Al2O3 could not only facilitate the conversions of HC/CO/NO, but also promote the generation of NH3, and the optimal content of La2O3 is 4 wt%. In addition, the stability test results shown in Fig. S1 tell us that after exposed in the reactive gas mixture for 100 h, the conversions of C3H8, C3H6, CO and NO for the four catalysts are similar with those for the original catalysts, and the concentration of NH3 appears to be a little higher, demonstrating that both Pd/Al2O3 and the La2O3-modified catalysts possess excellent catalytic stability. 3.2 Textural properties of the catalysts The textural parameters of the various catalysts, including specific surface areas (SBET), pore volumes (V) and pore diameters (D), are summarized in Table 1 . It can be seen therein that compared with bare Pd/Al2O3 catalyst (La0), the La2O3-containing catalysts show smaller pore diameters, pore volumes and surface areas. Considering that Al2O3 powders are thermally treated at a temperature as high as 1000 °C before impregnation of precious metal solution, which may bring about sintering of smaller pores and formation of larger ones, the relatively large diameter (21.8 nm) of La0 is understandable. After introduction of La2O3, which can act as a stabilizer for Al2O3, the deterioration of the pore structure upon high temperature treatment is effectively retarded, thus smaller pore diameters are maintained for La2, La4 and La8, which consequently leads to their smaller pore volumes and surface areas. Fig. 2 display the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of the various catalysts. As observed in Fig. 2(a), the isotherm of La0 can be identified as type IV and the hysteresis loop is similar with type H1, indicating that uniform cylindrical shape pores are present in La0. However, the hysteresis loops of the La2O3-containing catalysts seem to transform to type H2, meaning that ink-bottle shaped pores are presented. In addition, from Fig. 2(b), it is found that the pore sizes of La2, La4 and La8 are smaller than that of La0, and the distribution curves are narrower as well, which agrees well with the textural parameters listed in Table 1. 3.3 XRD characterization results XRD characterization was performed for the purpose of phase identification and the obtained patterns are compared in Fig. 3 . As is well known, when Al2O3 is obtained after calcination at relatively low temperature, it is probably presented as γ-Al2O3 phase, which is metastable and upon increasing calcination temperature, it would undergo gradual transformation into θ (or δ) and finally α-Al2O3 phase [26]. For bare Pd/Al2O3 catalyst (La0), θ-Al2O3 and PdO phase can be identified from its XRD pattern, which is understandable considering that the Al2O3 powders were thermally treated at 1000 °C prior to the impregnation process. As reported in the literatures [27-31], introduction of La2O3 into Al2O3 could effectively improve its stability at high temperatures, the atomically dispersed La3+ on Al2O3 surface appears to pin the oxygen substructure, thus hindering the reconstructive transformation of Al2O3 phase. It is found from Fig. 3 that although Al2O3 in La2 and La4 also presents as θ phase, their peak intensities become obviously lower, which can be attributed to the improved stability of Al2O3 induced by the introduction of La2O3, and moreover, the introduction of La2O3 could promote the dispersion of Pd species, especially for La4, the peaks characteristic of PdO phase of which are weakest, implying its highest dispersion of Pd species, which is consequently advantageous to its catalytic performance. However, for La8 with highest La2O3 content, although highest stability of Al2O3 is obtained, which could help Al2O3 predominantly maintain at γ-Al2O3 phase, undesirable catalytic performance is attained in respect that γ-Al2O3 is inferior to θ-Al2O3 to support Pd catalysts with excellent redox behavior [32,33]. On the other hand, the introduction of excessive amount of La2O3 is detrimental to the dispersion of Pd species, thus larger particles of PdO are observed, which may be another reason for its worse catalytic activity compared with La4. In addition, to disclose the evolution of phase structure of the catalysts during catalytic reaction process, the XRD patterns of the catalysts after reaction are collected and displayed in Fig. S2. It can be found therein that the crystal phase of Al2O3 for the four catalysts remains almost unchanged compared with the corresponding catalysts before reaction. However, peaks related to Pd species are absent, which is understandable in respect that PdO species would generally undergo reduction during three-way catalytic reaction process, and Pd species are more difficult to be detected by XRD technique. 3.4 27Al SSNMR analysis Chemical states of Al species in the catalysts were analyzed by 27Al SSNMR, and Fig. 4 (a) shows the obtained 27Al SSNMR spectra. Through curve fitting, three peaks at around 67 ppm, 55 ppm and 5.5 ppm are found for all samples, which is corresponded to three forms of coordination state of Al species typically presented in transitional alumina, that is, tetra-coordinated (Altetra), penta-coordinated (Alpenta) and octa-coordinated (Alocta) [34-38]. The ratios of Al species with different coordination states are calculated based on the peak areas of the three fitted peaks, and the results are compiled in Table 2 . It can be found therein that as the content of La2O3 increases, the ratio of Altetra gradually decreases, while the ratios of Alpenta and Alocta become larger. To better disclose the relationship between the content of La2O3 and the coordination state of Al species, the ratio of Altetra as a function of La2O3 content is depicted in Fig. 4(b), wherein it is found that the decrease of the ratio of Altetra is linearly correlated with the increase of La2O3 content. In addition, it is also reported that the formation of LaAlO3 by partial incorporation of La into the Al2O3 lattice would lead to stronger signals of Altetra [39]. Thus, the smaller ratio of Altetra after the introduction of La2O3 hints us that La2O3 is predominately distributed on the surface of Al2O3. In a word, it is reasonably inferred that the introduced La2O3 mainly interacts with Al2O3 by preferentially anchoring to the tetra-coordinated Al sites on the surface, which exerts positive influence on dispersing and stabilizing the ionic forms of Pd2+ on the surface of Al2O3. 3.5 Dispersion of Pd species Dispersion of Pd species is of critical importance to the catalysts in respect that it represents the metallic surface available for the catalytic reaction. Thus dispersion of Pd species is measured through CO chemisorption experiment and it is calculated under the assumption that the ratio of Pd to CO is 1:1, the obtained results are illustrated in Fig. 5 . As can be seen from Fig. 5, the dispersion of Pd species for the La2O3-modified catalysts is remarkably higher than that for bare Pd/Al2O3, demonstrating that the introduction of La2O3 could indeed promote the dispersion of Pd species, and the optimal content of La2O3 appears to be 4 wt%, which is well in line with the sequence of the three-way catalytic performance. 3.6 XPS study XPS study was performed to provide surface elemental information of the catalysts, the obtained Pd 3d, La 3d, Al 2p and O 1 s spectra are displayed in Fig. 6 , and the quantitative information about the surface elemental distribution, as well as the chemical states of Pd and O species, is summarized in Table 3 . As can be observed in Fig. 6(b), the peak intensity of La 3d increases with increasing La2O3 content, indicating that La is enriched on the surface, as also evidenced by the increasing relative amount of La in Table 3. Moreover, the binding energies of Al 2p (Fig. 6(c)) for the La2O3-modified samples shift to lower values, implying that the state of Al is affected by the addition of La2O3. This phenomenon is in good consistency with the 27Al SSNMR results. From Table 3, similar surface concentrations of Pd are observed for all catalysts, however, the chemical state of Pd varies to a large extent. Fig. 6(a) shows the curve fitting results of the Pd 3d XPS spectra, therein the XPS curves can be fitted into four peaks, which are assigned to as Pd0 3d5/2, Pd2+ 3d5/2, Pd0 3d3/2 and Pd2+ 3d3/2, respectively, from low to high binding energy direction [40,41]. Accordingly, the ratios of Pd2+ and Pd0 are calculated based on the relative areas of the four peaks. As can be found from Table 3, after La2O3 is introduced, the ratio of Pd2+ remarkably increases, especially for La4, the ratio of Pd2+ increases to 66.93%, meaning that the majority of Pd species on the surface of La4 is presented as PdO. Combining with the XRD results that the characteristic peaks of PdO phase are weakest for La4, it can be more affirmatively deduced that best dispersion state of Pd species is achieved for La4, which can well account for its superior three-way catalytic performance. With respect to the O 1 s spectra, as shown in Fig. 6(d), two types of oxygen species labeled as Oα and Oβ are resolved, and the relative ratios of Oα and Oβ are also listed in Table 3. It is generally accepted that Oα at lower binding energy is originated from lattice oxygen, and Oβ at higher binding energy is attributed to surface adsorbed oxygen, hydroxyl groups or oxygen vacancies [42]. Thus higher ratio of Oβ species is advantageous to the catalytic reactions in respect that Oβ has higher mobility than Oα [43]. Fortunately, it is found from Table 3 that the introduction of La2O3 into the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst system appears to be beneficial to obtain more Oβ species, and La4 with La2O3 content of 4 wt% possesses highest ratio of Oβ, which means largest amount of active oxygen species that can participate in the catalytic reaction process. 3.7 SEM and TEM observations SEM and TEM observations were conducted to disclose the morphological properties of the various catalysts, and the obtained images are displayed in Figs. 7-9 . From the SEM images in Fig. 7, it is found that large particles with compact morphology are presented in La0, and the La2O3-containing catalysts exhibit looser morphology with smaller particles, especially for La4 in Fig. 7(c), which could facilitate the transfer process of both the gaseous reactants and the products, thus consequently promote the catalytic conversion process. The TEM images in Fig. 8 can intuitively provide us some information about the dispersion of Pd species on the surface of the catalysts. As seen in Fig. 8(a), the black particles located on the gray substrate is possibly Pd species. While for the La2O3-containing catalysts, especially when the content of La2O3 is relatively higher, some crystalline La2O3 particles may be presented. In this case, the distinguish between La2O3 and Pd-related particles is difficult when the resolution of TEM measurement is not high enough. Notwithstanding, it can be roughly observed from Fig. 8 that the introduction of La2O3 into the Pd/Al2O3 system is advantageous for Pd species to achieve better dispersion state. Fig. 9 shows the HRTEM images of the various catalysts, wherein the particles labeled by red arrows are identified as PdO, those labeled by black arrows are recognized as metallic Pd particles, and the particles marked by yellow arrows are crystalline La2O3 particles. By careful comparison of the HRTEM images in Fig. 9, it is found that when appropriate amount of La2O3 in introduced, higher dispersion and smaller particles of Pd species are achieved for La2 and La4, which is favorable to the three-way catalytic performance. However, when the amount of La2O3 is excessive, crystalline La2O3 particles are detected for La8, which is detrimental to the dispersion of Pd species. 3.8 H2-TPR analysis H2-TPR analysis was performed to investigate the reduction property of the various catalysts, and the results are illustrated in Fig. 10 . Therein the reduction peaks are generated from the reduction of oxidative Pd2+ species in the catalysts. As is well known, when Pd species is loaded on Al2O3 support, the reduction of oxidative Pd2+ species usually takes place at considerably low temperatures [44,45]. As displayed in Fig. 10, the reduction of La0 begins at ca. 43 °C and the peak maximum appears at 62 °C. When La2O3 is introduced into the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst system, the reduction occurs at obviously lower temperatures in respect that the introduction of La2O3 could facilitate the dissociation of molecular H2 into H species on active surface sites, as a result, the following reduction of Pd2+ species could proceed more easily. Thus, the reduction of Pd2+ species may start at temperature lower than 40 °C. This may be a reason for the production of larger amount of NH3 during the three-way catalytic reaction process. On the other hand, when the content of La2O3 is excessively high, crystalline La2O3 is formed, which is detrimental to the dispersion of Pd species, consequently higher reduction temperature and more complicated reduction peak are obtained for La8. 3.9 NH3-TPD analysis Fig. 11 displays the NH3-TPD profiles of the various catalysts. In general, the NH3-TPD profiles can be categorized into two regions, that is, the desorption peak in the low-temperature range is ascribed to the weak acidic site on the surface of the catalyst, and the desorption peak in the high-temperature range is correlated with the strong acidic site [46]. As observed in Fig. 11, when La2O3 is introduced into the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst system, the desorption peak of NH3 in the high-temperature region becomes weaker, and the peak in the low-temperature region becomes somewhat stronger. As confirmed by 27Al SSNMR results, the introduced La2O3 mainly interacts with Al2O3 by preferentially anchoring to the tetra-coordinated Al sites on the surface, which can account for the decreased amount of strong acidic site on the surface. In addition, the prominent desorption performance of NH3 in low-temperature region for the La2O3-modified catalysts is beneficial to the production of NH3 during the three-way catalytic reaction process. Furthermore, for La8 with excessive content of La2O3, the complicated phase structure is responsible for the multiplet peaks of NH3 desorption. 4 Conclusions In this work, La2O3 was introduced into the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst system to promote its three-way catalytic (TWC) performance for passive selective catalytic reduction (pSCR) operation, based on the results and discussion above, the following conclusions can be drawn: 1) The introduced La2O3 mainly interacts with Al2O3 by preferentially anchoring to the tetra-coordinated Al sites on the surface. 2) The introduction of appropriate amount of La2O3 could suppress the particle aggregation of Al2O3 and promote the dispersion of Pd species, in addition, more Pd2+ species and active oxygen species are presented. 3) The low-temperature reduction capability and desorption property of NH3 are improved by the modification of La2O3. 4) Pd/Al2O3 catalyst modified by appropriate amount of La2O3 exhibits superior conversion efficiency of HC/CO/NO, as well as larger amount of NH3 production, and the optimal content of La2O3 is 4 wt%. 5) While excessive amount of La2O3 is introduced, crystalline La2O3 is formed, which is detrimental to the dispersion of Pd species and consequently results in declined three-way catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: For three-way catalysts (TWC) applied in lean burn gasoline engines for passive selective catalytic reduction (pSCR) operation, besides the conversion efficiency of HC/CO/NO, the production of NH3 is also an important concern. In this work, La2O3 was introduced into the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst system, the influence on its TWC performance for pSCR operation was investigated, and the physicochemical properties were characterized by a range of techniques. The results reveal that the introduced La2O3 mainly interacts with Al2O3 by preferentially anchoring to the tetra-coordinated Al sites on the surface. When the catalyst is modified by appropriate amount of La2O3 (4 wt%), higher dispersion of Pd species, larger amount of Pd2+ and active oxygen species are achieved, which well contributes to improved low-temperature reduction ability and NH3 desorption property of the catalyst. As a consequence, excellent catalytic conversions of HC/CO/NO are obtained, and meanwhile, higher concentration of NH3 is generated, making the modified catalyst more promising for pSCR operation.
